html:
Your Family Needs Power. Not Promises.

Look, we both know why you're here. The apagones aren't getting better—they're getting longer. And your tía is tired of losing everything in the fridge while the government figures out what century it wants to live in. Solar isn't a luxury anymore. It's survival infrastructure. The question isn't if you should send panels to Cuba—it's which ones will actually work when they get there, survive the humidity, and generate enough juice to keep the essentials running during those 8, 10, 12-hour blackouts.

Here's what nobody tells you about sending solar panels to Cuba: portability matters more than raw wattage. Why? Because customs is unpredictable, shipping costs are calculated by dimensional weight, and your family might need to move the setup between apartments or even provinces. A 400W foldable panel that fits in a suitcase beats a rigid 600W monster that costs $300 to ship and might get "inspected" into oblivion.

The other thing—and I cannot stress this enough—is that you need a complete system, not just panels. Panels without a charge controller are paperweights. Panels without a battery bank are daytime-only solutions. Some of the kits below include everything; others assume you're piecing it together. I'll be clear about which is which.

One more reality check: Cuban electrical infrastructure runs on 110V/220V depending on the neighborhood and the mood of the grid. Most of these panels output 12V or 24V DC, which means you'll need an inverter to run household appliances. Some kits include them. Most don't. Budget accordingly.

The Short Version

If you want the best balance of power, portability, and Cuba-proof durability, the Renogy 400W Portable Solar Panel Suitcase is the one. IP67 waterproof, folds into a manageable package, and has kickstands that actually work. It's not cheap, but it's the panel your family will still be using five years from now.

See the Renogy 400W Suitcase →
8-12

Average blackout hours in Cuban provinces (2025 data)

The One to Beat

Editor's Pick

Renogy 400W Portable Solar Panel Suitcase

4.4★ $$$$$ tier

VERDICT: The gold standard for Cuba-bound solar. This thing is built like it expects to be dropped, dragged through customs, and set up on a rooftop in Holguín. IP67 waterproof means it laughs at tropical storms. The suitcase design with sturdy kickstands means your family doesn't need engineering degrees to set it up. 23% efficiency isn't the absolute highest, but it's consistent and reliable.

The catch? You'll need a charge controller and battery bank separately. But that's actually a feature—it means your family can upgrade components over time without replacing the whole system.

Check Price on Amazon →
"Portability isn't a luxury—it's insurance against customs, moving, and whatever else Cuba throws at you."

Best Portable Options

These fold, travel, and won't bankrupt you on shipping. Perfect for families who rent or might need to relocate.

Best Value Portable

Renogy 400W Solar Panel Blanket

4.6★ $$$$$

25% efficiency with N-Type cells—that's legitimately impressive. The 16-fold design is wild; this thing packs down smaller than a yoga mat. Lighter than the suitcase version too. The tradeoff? Less structural rigidity, so it needs a flat surface or creative mounting.

View Details →

Renogy 200W Portable Panel

4.5★ $$$$$

Starter-friendly. IP65 waterproof, foldable, and half the wattage means half the shipping cost. Good for testing the waters or supplementing an existing setup.

Check Price →

How Much Solar Does Your Family Actually Need?

Plug in the typical blackout duration and see which setup makes sense.

Complete Systems (Everything Included)

For families who don't want to piece things together—or for you if you don't want to explain charge controllers over WhatsApp.

Best Complete System

ECO-WORTHY 9.36KWH 2340W 48V Complete System

4.4★ (445 reviews) $$$$$ tier

VERDICT: The "never worry about power again" option. This is serious infrastructure—12 panels, a 5000W all-in-one inverter, mounting brackets, the works. 9.36KWH of storage means your family can run a fridge, fans, lights, and charge phones through an entire overnight blackout. Plug and play design means minimal installation headaches.

The reality check: This is heavy, expensive to ship, and requires roof space. Best for families who own their home and have a dedicated installation spot. Not for apartment dwellers.

Check Price on Amazon →
Best Starter Kit

Renogy 100W 12V Solar Panel Starter Kit

4.6★ (465 reviews) $$$$$

The gateway drug to solar independence. Includes the panel, 30A PWM charge controller, adaptor kit, cables, and Z brackets. Everything except the battery. Perfect for families who want to start small and expand later—or test whether solar works for their situation before going all-in.

View Details →

ECO-WORTHY 200W 12V/24V Solar Panel Kit

4.6★ (465 reviews) $$$$$

Double the power, same simplicity. High-efficiency monocrystalline panels with a 30A PWM controller. The 12V/24V flexibility means it works with most battery banks available in Cuba. Solid middle-ground option for families who need more than 100W but aren't ready for a full system.

View Details →

High-Wattage Showdown

When you need maximum power and have the roof space to match. These are the heavy hitters.

Top Pick - High Wattage

SUNGOLDPOWER 560W Bifacial (6-Pack)

4.3★ (435) $$$$$
  • ✓ 3,360W total (6 x 560W)
  • ✓ Bifacial design captures reflected light
  • ✓ Up to 30% efficiency
  • ✓ N-Type 16BB cells
  • ⚠️ Requires professional installation
Check Price →
Runner-Up

Renogy 320W Solar Panels (2-Pack)

4.3★ (43) $$$$$
  • ✓ 640W total (2 x 320W)
  • ✓ 18BB N-Type cells
  • ✓ 25% cell efficiency
  • ✓ 12/24V compatible
  • ✓ Easier to ship than 6-pack
Check Price →

The verdict: SUNGOLDPOWER wins on raw power and efficiency, but the Renogy 2-pack is more practical for shipping. If your family has a large roof and you can coordinate freight shipping, go SUNGOLDPOWER. For most situations, the Renogy pair hits the sweet spot.

Compare Side-by-Side

The Budget Play

Not everyone can drop $$$$$ on solar. These options punch above their weight class.

Best Budget

DOKIO 100W 18V Panel

4.3★ (435) $$$

The only mid-range option on this list. Glass module, aluminum frame, pre-drilled holes. No frills, just works. Perfect for testing solar viability before committing to bigger systems.

Check Price →

ECO-WORTHY 400W (4x100W)

4.5★ (455) $$$$$

Modular expansion. Four 100W panels means you can ship in batches or set up incrementally. Good value per watt, and the smaller panel size is easier to position on irregular rooftops.

Check Price →

N-Type 400W Bifacial (2x200W)

4.6★ (465) $$$$$

Anti-shade design is clutch. Dual-module parallel setup means partial shading doesn't kill the whole system. 25% efficiency. Bifacial captures reflected light from rooftops.

Check Price →

Also Worth Considering

Renogy 200W N-Type 24V Panel

4.6★ $$$$$

The efficiency king. 25% cell efficiency with 16BB design. 24V output is ideal for larger battery banks. Rigid panel, so factor in shipping dimensions.

View Details →

What Will Shipping Actually Cost?

Solar panels are bulky. Use this to estimate before you commit.

The Bottom Line

For most families in Cuba, the Renogy 400W Suitcase is the move. It's portable enough to survive customs and apartment moves, powerful enough to matter during 8+ hour blackouts, and built to handle tropical humidity. Pair it with a charge controller and battery bank, and your family has genuine energy independence.

If budget is tight, start with the DOKIO 100W at the $$$ tier—it's the only mid-range option here and a solid proof-of-concept before scaling up. And if your family owns their home and has roof space? The ECO-WORTHY complete system is a one-time investment that pays for itself in peace of mind.

Get the Renogy 400W Suitcase → Budget Option: DOKIO 100W →
